title-group.article-title: A comprehensive review: Biological activity, modification and synthetic methodologies of prenylated flavonoids

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Prenylated flavonoids Biological activity
Synthesis
Structure–activity relationships
ABSTRACT

Prenylated flavonoids, a unique class of flavonoids which combine a flavonoid skeleton and a lipophilic prenyl side-chain, possess great potential biological activities including cytotoxicity, anti-inflammation, anti-Alzheimer, anti-microbial, anti-oxidant, anti-diabetes, estrogenic, vasorelaxant and enzyme inhibition. Recently, prenylated flavonoids have become an indispensable anchor for the development of new therapeutic agents, and have received increasing from medicinal chemists. The prenylated flavonoids have been outstanding developed through isolation, semi or fully synthesis in a very short period of time, which proves the great value in medicinal chemistry researches. In this review, research progress of prenylated flavonoids including natural prenylated flavonoids, structural modification, synthetic methodologies and pharmacological activities was summarized comprehensively. Furthermore, the structure–activity relationships (SARs) of prenylated flavonoids were summarized which provided a basis for the selective design and optimization of multifunctional prenylated flavonoid derivatives for the treatment of multi-factorial diseases in clinic.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The objective of this review was to provide the pharmacological activities of prenylated flavonoids and their derivatives isolated from plants, semi or fully synthesized with different functional groups at different positions of their skeletons from 2000 to 2021. In addition, the structure–activity relationships (SARs) of prenylated flavonoids in terms of cytotoxicity, anti-inflammation, anti-Alzheimer, anti-microbial, antioxidant, anti-diabetes, estrogenic, vasorelaxant and enzyme inhibition were reviewed according to literature reports. Moreover, the regioselective syntheses methods of various prenylated flavonoids were also summarized in this paper.

sec.title: 2. Chemistry
2.1. Biosynthetic pathway for prenylated flavonoids
3. Pharmacological activities of prenylated flavonoids
3.1. Cytotoxicity
sec.p:
Cancer in various forms is one of the deadliest health hazards, which has always been one of the major challenges facing humanity. It involves the cell proliferation, differentiation, angiogenesis, and apoptosis of the normal cells which leads to tumor conditions. In order to reduce the human mortality or suppress the further development of cancer, chemoprevention and chemotherapy are a common treatment method. Although various anticancer agents have been used to treat different kinds of cancers through acting on different mechanisms, these agents are not only cytotoxicity towards tumor cells but also normal cells due to their lack of selectivity. Therefore, the acquisition of anti-tumor drugs from natural products has attracted more and more attention from medicinal chemists. Prenylated flavonoids are a large group of naturally occurring flavonoids characterized by the presence of a prenylated side-chain on the flavonoid skeleton. The prenyl side-chain could enhance the binding affinity of flavonoids toward P-glycoprotein, which results in remarkable improvement of biological activity of the flavonoids (
). In recent research, prenylated flavonoids have been recognized as compounds with potential cytotoxicity against various cancer cells.

Soon afterwards, a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 20–27 ) were isolated from
Macaranga kurzii (Euphorbiaceae)
and
Macaranga indica (Euphorbiaceaae)
, and their cytotoxicity against A549 and Hep G2 cancer cell lines were evaluated. However, most of the compounds did not possess obvious cytotoxicity against these cancer cell lines (
, b;
, b). Daphnegiravone D ( 28 ) is a typical diprenyl flavone isolated from
Daphne giraldii (Euphorbiaceaae)
by our research group, which bearing the prenyl side chain position at C-8 on the A ring and C-3 ′ on the B ring, respectively (
, b). The cytotoxic activities in vitro of daphnegiravone D against nine human cancer cell lines and one normal hepatic cell line were evaluated by using MTT assay with 5-Fluorouracil as positive control. And the result indicated that daphnegiravone D exhibited potent cytotoxicity in a concentration and time-dependent manner against human hepatoma Hep3B and HepG2 cells with IC 50 values of 1.63 μM and 9.89 μM, respectively, but exhibited no apparent cytotoxicity on human normal cells. The subsequent mechanism study suggested that daphnegiravone D could arrest cell cycle at G0/G1 phase and induce apoptosis through regulating p38 and JNK/MAPK pathways in Hep3B and HepG2 cells. Moreover, in vivo studies demonstrated that daphnegiravone D could significantly inhibit tumor growth in a nude mouse xenograft model by suppressing the proliferation of tumor cells. In addition, a chemical study on the leaves of
Epimedium Koreanum Nakai
have resulted in the discovery of several prenylated flavones (
). Subsequently, MTT assays showed that epimedokoreanin B ( 30 ) exhibited the most potent cytotoxicity against lung cancer A549 and NCIH292 cells among these prenylated flavones with IC 50 value of 5.6 and 7.9 μM, respectively, in contrast, baohuoside I ( 29 ) showed almost nontoxic activity with IC 50 > 50 μM. Comparing the structures of these compounds, it was suggested that the position of prenyl, hydroxyl and glycosyl groups within the flavonoids played a critical role in the viability inhibitory effects of lung cancer cells. Glycosylation of the flavonoid and hydroxylation of the prenyl side chain decreased the cytotoxicity of the compounds, which might be related to the increasing of hydrophilicity of the prenylated flavonoids.

The relationship between the structures of prenylated flavonoids and cytotoxic activities on human cancer cells indicates the following common structures: (a) the prenyl side chain position at C-8 on the A ring of prenylated flavonoids could be a crucial active unit, and cyclization or hydroxylation of the prenyl side chain would dramatically decrease cytotoxicity (compound 1 vs 5 , 30 vs 32 , 42 vs 48 , 54 vs 53 , 42 vs 45 ); (b) the prenyl side chain present C-3 at C ring of prenylated flavonoids, could significantly improve cytotoxicity (compound 72 vs 73 ); (c) featuring a prenyl side chain present C-8 at A ring and C-3 ′ at B ring, respectively, may lead to the most potent cytotoxic lead compound (compounds 33 and 77 ); (d) glycosylation of 3-OH at C ring of prenylated flavonoids or hydroxylation of the prenyl side chain could decrease cytotoxicity a lot (compound 30 vs 29 and 31 ) ( Fig. 8 ).

sec.title: 3.2. Anti-inflammation
sec.p: a nt: not tested. b Positive control.

In a recent study, Yongsheng Chen and co-workers semi-synthesized the rare prenylated flavonoid isolaxifolin ( 369 ) through the five-step reaction sequences ( Fig. 10 ), with the natural apigenin as the starting material (
). They investigated the impact of compound 369 at five concentrations up to 6.2 μM on certain pro-inflammatory cytokines in murine macrophage RAW 264.7 cells, and the result showed that compound 369 could reduce the secretion of NO, TNF-α, and IL- 6 in a dose-independent manner.

Aforementioned outcome suggested that the relationship between the structure of prenylated flavonoids and anti-inflammatory activity indicates the following common structures: (a) the keto group at position C-4, and the hydroxy groups at positions C-5, C-7, and C-4 ′ of the prenyl flavonoid skeleton are important structural elements for anti-inflammatory activity; (b) the double bond between C-2 and C-3 does not have a great effect on the anti-inflammatory activity (compounds 33 , 273 , 287–289 and 292 ); (c) the cyclization of the prenyl moiety in C-6 or C-8 also can contribute the inhibitory activity against the COX, TNF-α and NO production (compounds 282 , 296 and 341 ); (d) two prenyl side chains positioned on ring A and C, respectively, exhibit the most potent anti-inflammatory activity (compounds 33 , 282 and 296 ); (e) the prenylated isoflavones have remarkable inhibitory activity against NO production, and the methoxy group at position C-7 is beneficial to increase the activity (compounds 354–358 ) ( Fig. 11 ).

sec.title: 3.4.1. Antibacterial activity
sec.p:
It is well known that plants could produce a variety of chemicals to survive attacks by microbial invasion. Five prenylated flavonoids ( 388–392 ) ( Fig. 13 ) ( Table 7 ) were isolated from the stems and roots of
Tripterygium wilfordii
(Celastraceae) and screened for antibacterial effects against several bacterial strains such as Cryptococcus neoformans , Pseudomonas aeruginosa , vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis , methicillinresistant Staphylococcus aureus, and Staphylococcus aureus , which was done using modified versions of the NCCLS methods (
). The results indicated that these prenylated flavonoids possessed promising antimicrobial activity (IC 50 < 5.0 μg/ml). Particularly, compounds
389
and 392 exhibited more potent antimicrobial activity against C. neoformans with IC 50 values of 2.95 μg/mL and 1.06 μg/mL, respectively. In addition , compound 383
was especially active against MRSA (IC 50 values of 2.07 and 2.60 μg/mL, respectively) and S. aureus (2.01 and 2.16 μg/mL, respectively).

Moreover, icaritin, is an excellent natural scaffold for further modification to obtain more effective derivatives. Several new series of icaritin derivatives ( 393–412 ) were designed and synthesized by the Liu group ( Figs. 14 , 15 ) (
). The antibacterial effects of these derivatives were tested in Mueller-Hinton broth by standard broth microdilution methods, and the result ( Table 8 ) indicated that most of derivatives were more active against four Gram-positive bacterial strains, including MRSA,
Staphylococcus aureus
and
Bacillus cereus
. Among them, compound 396 , containing two arginine residues, was the most active of all the tested compounds with MICs values ranging from 1.56 to 3.13 μg/mL. In addition, compound 396 also exhibited potent in vivo antimicrobial activity in the
S.aureus
29213-infected mouse keratitis model, with comparable capability as the positive control levofloxacin. Based on these data, it was suggested that the greatest improvement in antimicrobial activity was attributed to the strong electrostatic interaction between the compounds which bearing positively charged groups and the negatively charged bacterial membrane.

sec.title: 3.4.2. Anti-parasite
sec.p:
Haruki Yamada and co-workers have been screening antimalarial activity against the multi-drug-resistant
Plasmodium falciparum
of the medicinal plants, and they demonstrated that five prenylated flavonoids ( 413–417) ( Fig. 13 ) from the stem bark of
Erythrina fusca (Leguminosae)
showed a good antimalarial activity which was conducted using the multi-drug-resistant (K1) and sensitive (FCR3) strains of
P.falciparum
( Table 7 ) (
). Among them, compounds 416 exhibited the most potent activity with IC 50 values of 1.6 μg/ml, while compounds 413 and 415 did not exhibit such significant activity, even though the structures of these compounds also possess the same prenyl group. This result suggested that the position of prenylation rather than the number of prenyl groups determines to the construction of more potent antimalarial agents.

Similarly, a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 418–430 ) ( Fig. 13 ) was isolated from
Erythrina latissima (Leguminosae)
and tested for their antiplasmodial activity against
P.falciparum
strain K1 ( Table 7 ) (
). The result indicated that most of compounds showed a moderate potent activity, and compounds 420 , 424 , 425 , 427 and 430 contained underivatised prenyl substituents and exhibited remarkable biological activities with IC 50 values of < 5 μM. The structure-activity relationship indicated that the underivatised prenyl substituents at the flavonoid skeleton contribute to more potent antiplasmodial activity than the prenyl side chain is converted to a 6-membered ring.

sec.title: 3.5. Antioxidant activity
sec.p:
In order to search for natural products which can be used for scavenging free radicals, Wen-Chun Lan et al. obtained a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 78 , 329 , 434–444 ) ( Figs. 3 , 9 , 16 ) from
Artocarpus altilis (Moraceae)
and tested their free radical-scavenging activities through ABTS •+ , O 2 • , and DPPH assays (
). Unfortunately, the result indicated that most compounds showed either moderate or no scavenging effects. Compounds 436 and 444 whose structures possess two or three hydroxyl group substituents on the B-ring, exhibited the better radical-scavenging activities, and antioxidant activity is ranked as follows: 436 > 444 Based on these data, the SAR outcome revealed that as the number of hydroxyl groups on the B-ring increased, the scavenging effects of prenylated flavonoids also increased. Moreover, two hydroxyl groups adjacent to each other showed the better scavenging effects.

sec.title: 3.6. Anti-diabetes
3.7. Estrogenic activity
sec.p:
Prenylated flavonoids represent one of the largest groups of phytoestrogens, not only with a chemical structure resembles 17β- estradiol but also the ability to mimic estrogen activity (
). Two prenylated flavonoids named glabrene ( 466 ) and glabridin ( 467 ) ( Fig. 17 ) were isolated from
Glycyrrhiza glabra (Fabaceae)
by Rudy
. The estrogen-like activities of both compounds have been tested by three systems including competitive ligand binding assays in vitro cell assays and in vivo animal models. The outcome indicated that compounds 466 and 467 bind with the estrogen receptor closely, with EC 50 values of 5 × 10 5 M and 5 × 10 6 M, respectively ( Table 11 ).

In addition, four prenylated flavonoids 468–471 ( Fig. 18 ) were synthesized and exhibited significantly estrogen-like activity in MCF-7/ BOS cells. However, the specific inhibition rates or IC 50 was not provided in the reference, and the estrogenic potency of these compounds is ranked as follows: 469 > 471 > 470 > 468 . The outcome suggested compounds 469 and 470 contained the prenyl moiety at C-8 whose estrogen-like activity was more potent than compound 468 containing the prenyl moiety at C-6, which revealed that the 8-prenyl substituent could markedly improve the estrogenic activity (
). According to these data, it was observed that the location of prenyl group at ring A of flavonoids could significantly affect the osteogenic activity. In particularly, the prenylflavonoids with C-8 prenylation may represent a class of flavonoids with a higher osteogenic activity.

sec.title: 3.9.3. cGMP and phosphodiesterase 5 inhibition
3.9.4. Neuraminidase inhibition
3.9.5. Indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 1 inhibition
3.9.6. Phosphodiesterase-4 inhibition
sec.p: The initial relationship between the structure of prenylated flavonoids and enzyme inhibition activity indicates the following common structures: (a) presence of the 2 ′ ,4 ′ -OH moiety on the B ring can significantly improve the tyrosinase inhibitory activity, but the keto group at position C-4 does not have a great effect on the tyrosinase inhibition (compounds 502 and 503 ); (b) the double bond between C-2 and C-3 are important structural elements for cGMP-PDE5 inhibitory activity (compounds 519 vs 516–518 ); (c) the 3 ′ ,4 ′ -OH moiety of the prenyl flavonoid skeleton are important structural elements for neuraminidase inhibition (compounds 522 vs 523, 525 vs 527 ); (d) formation of 2 H -pyran ring between 3-prenyl moiety and 2 ′ -OH can significantly increase the PDE4 inhibition activity (compounds 537 and 538 vs 79 ) ( Fig. 22 ).

sec.title: 4. Chemical synthesis
sec.p:
Though prenylated flavonoids have attractive pharmacological properties, and their occurrence in plant extracts is complicated by the relatively complex mixtures, which means their mass isolation from the plants is not economically attractive (
). Several synthetic methods have been developed and modified to get products of high yield, purity and of the desired quality. As the backbone of prenylated flavonoids consist of the rings of C6–C3–C6, and they are referred to as A, C, and B rings, respectively. Thus, the prenyl side-chain can be substituted on different rings via different synthesis methods. Herein, we have focused predominantly on reviewing the development of various strategies toward the total synthesis of prenylated flavonoids.

sec.title: 4.1. Total synthesis of A-ring prenylated flavonoids
sec.p: a Compounds with inhibition greater than 50% at 10 μM were further determined for corresponding IC values.
50 b Values are represented as means ± SD based on three independent experiments.
c Positive control.

The development of a straightforward and tunable entry into C-6 and C-8 prenyl flavonoids from a common precursor would play a significant role in the field of biological activities of prenylated flavonoids. Recently, Wei Li and co-workers reported the regioselective syntheses of C-8 and C-6 prenyl substitution on flavonoids via intramolecular [1,3] or [1,5] shift reaction of 5- O -prenylflavonoids catalyzed by acidic clay (
, 2019). Under the catalysis of Florisil clay in toluene, a series of C-8 prenyl flavonoids were obtained in good yields, and C-6 prenyl flavonoids were synthesized under the catalysis of Montmorillonite K10 clay, which started from commercially available and inexpensive precursor including diosmetin, quercetin and luteolin ( Fig. 25 ).

sec.title: 4.2. Total synthesis of B-ring prenylated flavonoids
4.3. Total synthesis of C-ring prenylated flavonoids
5. Conclusions
sec.p: In this review, the research progress of biosynthesis, biological activities, semi- and fully synthesis of prenylated flavonoids was comprehensively summarized. Compelling evidences indicated that prenylation might increase the bioactivities of their backbone flavonoids. Therefore, prenylated flavonoids have the potential to be developed as new drugs or supplements. So far, a few prenylated flavonoids have been clinically studied, such as icaritin. From this perspective, prenylated flavonoids are good clues for drug discovery, which provides an opportunity to design more selective and active isoprene based prenylated flavonoids for the treatment of multifactorial diseases. Besides, the underlying action mechanisms and clinical studies of the prenylated flavonoids need to be explored in further studies.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Shaochun Shi (born in 1996 in Hunan , China ) got his bachelor’ s and master’ s degree from Shenyang Pharmaceutical University in 2018 and 2021, respectively. His master thesis was studies on the structural modification and biological evaluation of flavonoids including prenylated flavonoids. He started to study for the PhD in Medicinal Chemistry at China Pharmaceutical University in 2021.

Jichong Li (born in 1997 in JiLin , China ) got his bachelor’ s from Changchun University of Chinese Medicine in 2019. He is studying for master’ s degree in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. His master project was studies on the structural modification and biological evaluation of prenylated flavonoids including Icariin and Icaritin.

Xuemei Zhao (born in 1968 in Shenyang, China ) is an associate professor in School of Shenyang Pharmaceutical University.She worked as a translator for Year Book of Health People’ s Republic of China published by People’ s Medical Publishing House for twelve years successively, from 2006 to 2017. She proofread the English edition of some textbooks, including Experiments on Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. She is the part time English editor for Asian Journal of Social Pharmacy.

Dr. Qingbo Liu (born in 1984 in Shenyang, China ) is associate professor of School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. He got M.Sc. and Ph.D in Natural Medicinal Chemistry from Shenyang Pharmaceutical University in 2010 and 2015 respectively. From 2016 to 2018, he worked as a postdoctoral researcher at ToHo University, Japan . His research interests include the isolation and structural modification of antiviral and antitumor active natural products.

Professor Shao-jiang Song (born in 1970 in Shenyang, China ) is the vice president in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. Prof. Song performed his PhD in pharmaceutical chemistry 2000 at Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. Prof. Song has published > 200 SCI articles on medicinal plants chemistry for finding bioactive compounds as new anti-tumor and anti-AD medicine leads. He has conducted research on the prenylated flavonoids for up to 10 years and some studies are published in the journal including European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry, Journal of Natural Products, Scientific Reports, Chemico-Biological Interactions, Biomedicine & Pharmacotherapy, Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters and so on.
